title: Unilateral Conductive Hearing Loss with Tinnitus and Dizziness
chief_complaint: I've noticed a decrease in hearing in my right ear that started years ago, but now I feel like I can't hear anything from that side.

problem_summary.functional_impact: Patient feels she cannot hear from the right side.

history.present_illness: Patient reports progressive hearing loss in the right ear over many years. She also reports tinnitus in the right ear and recent onset of dizziness.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear shows severe rising to moderately severe conductive hearing loss (significant air-bone gap) in the low-to-mid frequencies, sloping at 8000 Hz. Left ear shows essentially normal hearing sensitivity with a slight sensorineural dip at 500-1000 Hz.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: SRT scores agree with PTA. Word recognition is excellent in the left ear and good (slight difficulty) in the right ear when presented at suprathreshold levels.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Normal tympanograms bilaterally (Type A), indicating normal eardrum mobility despite the conductive loss.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Right ear: Absent reflexes for both ipsilateral and contralateral stimulation. Left ear: Normal ipsilateral reflexes; absent contralateral stimulation (due to right ear probe effect).

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with a significant unilateral conductive hearing loss in the right ear, characterized by a large air-bone gap and absent acoustic reflexes, yet normal tympanograms (Type A). The left ear has essentially normal hearing. This pattern—conductive loss with intact tympanic membrane mobility—is highly consistent with otosclerosis.
counseling_points: Your hearing test shows a 'conductive' hearing loss in your right ear. This means the inner ear nerve is working well, but sound is not being conducted efficiently through the middle ear bones.
Even though your eardrum moves normally (as shown by the pressure test), the bones behind it appear stiff, which prevents sound from getting through.
This condition is consistent with Otosclerosis, a fixation of the stapes bone.
Because the inner nerve is healthy, you have two main options: a surgical procedure to replace the stiff bone (stapedectomy) or using a hearing aid to amplify sound through the blockage.
We should also monitor the dizziness you mentioned with the ENT physician.
notes_for_actor: You are frustrated that your right ear feels 'dead' and has been getting worse for years.
You hear a ringing sound (tinnitus) in the bad ear.
You are currently undecided about whether you want surgery or a hearing aid; you are weighing your options.
